Concept - Instructional Approaches
A tenth-grade English teacher wants her class to use a wide variety of resources and technology in their end-of-year project. She asks each student to use three online sources and two written sources and incorporate a multimedia presentation to show the class. After class, four students who have limited opportunities and technological resources outside of school approach her and express their concern that they may not be able to fulfill all the project requirements because of their limited means. The teacher can best respond and meet the needs of the students using which of the following strategies?
A
Give each student a clear set of written instructions for the project so they can reference the expectations throughout the activity.
Option A is the wrong answer.
Explanation:
Providing the students with written instructions, although a good practice, does not address their concerns.
B
Place students into small groups that consist of students of varying means and abilities while also structuring class time so all students have equal access to the school's equipment. It will be important to let each student know the after-school hours available to access the school resources.

explanation:
Using groups of students of varying means allows the responsibilities between the students to be split to best accommodate individual situations. Also, giving each student equal access to the school resources provides all students the means to meet the minimum requirements of the project.
C
Place the four students into a group and allow them to have more class time with the school resources than the other groups.
D
Design the project so each activity can be completed using only the school library and a paper notebook. The teacher can give an opportunity for extra credit for the use of outside resources and technology.

Concept - Social and Academic Language
Mr. Freeman is giving his tenth-grade science class an end-of-unit exam. His class includes several English learners and his school supports Linguistic Accommodated Testing (LAT). During the exam, an English learner raises his hand and asks, "What does extinct mean?" How should Mr. Freeman respond?
A
"Please ask another student."
B
"I can't tell you, but I can give you a hint. Dinosaurs are extinct."
C
"Extinct means without any living members. When a species is extinct, it doesn't exist anymore."

explanation:
Linguistic Accommodated Testing (LAT) is used for various content area tests and encompasses an effort either to either simplify the language used in the test or allow the use of tools like glossaries. With this type of testing, it's acceptable for students to raise their hands and ask for assistance related to language, but not to content, as in the case of a definition. It can be assumed that tenth-grade native speakers know the meaning of the word "extinct," so explaining the meaning to an ELL is not giving them an unfair advantage.

"I'm sorry, but I cannot tell you."

choices.B:
While covering a unit on geography, a history teacher assigns each student to a country and requires them to make a presentation describing the problems faced by people living in the country due to the geography and the effects of the geography on the culture.

choices.D: A literature teacher who in the past has discussed only American and British authors spends some time discussing authors from other parts of the world and their different styles of writing.

explanation: This describes the additive approach, in which content, themes, and perspectives are also added to the curriculum without changing its basic structure or purpose.
